item.title: Brexit and the trade relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom with other countries.
item.description:
Some Brexit supporters have a relaxed view of European Union (EU) law. However, their assertions about trade after Brexit, specifically the notion that existing agreements would simply continue, require closer examination. They argue that global trade regulations would prevent the EU from hindering the UK’s trade relationships. This overlooks the possibility that, absent a transitional agreement, the UK’s participation in the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and other trade agreements could be at risk...

item.title: Is Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union considered valid?
item.description:
Bartlomiej Kulpa, LLM (London), PhD Candidate (Amsterdam) @KulpaBart Introduction The Treaty of Lisbon introduced Article 50 to the Treaty on European Union (TEU), establishing the legal framework for exiting the European Union (EU). This article acknowledges the possibility of withdrawal, a concept many legal experts believed existed even before the Treaty of Lisbon. Article 50 TEU outlines the withdrawal procedure. However, some argue that it contradicts the EU’s fundamental nature and weakens member states’ commitment to European integration, raising questions about the ideal withdrawal mechanism...

item.description:
